facts.text: This is a Criminal Appeal No. 169 of 1959 in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 169 of 1959. Appeal by special leave

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 27, 1958, of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 785 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 27, 1958, of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 785 of 1955. Nuruddin Ahmad

facts.text: Judgment delivered on December 7, 1960 by K. DAS, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. December 7. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by K. DAS, J.-This is an appeal by special leave

facts.text: Allahabad High Court on March 27, 1958 maintained conviction of appellant under s. 5(2) of Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947 but reduced sentence to two years rigorous imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by K. DAS, J.-This is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order of the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad dated March 27, 1958, whereby the said High Court maintained the conviction of the appellant under s. 5(2) of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947 (2 of 1947) but reduced the sentence of four years rigorous imprisonment passed on the appellant by the Special Judge, Kanpur, to two years rigorous imprisonment.

facts.text: Special Judge, Kanpur passed sentence of four years rigorous imprisonment on the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: ...Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947 (2 of 1947) but reduced the sentence of four years rigorous imprisonment passed on the appellant by the Special Judge, Kanpur, to two years rigorous imprisonment.

facts.text: Appellant Surajpal Singh was employed in the Police Department of the Uttar Pradesh Government.

anchor.surface_text: The short facts are these. The appellant Surajpal Singh was employed in the Police Department of the Uttar Pradesh Government.

facts.text: Appellant started service as a constable on salary of Rs. 13 per month from August 1, 1930.

anchor.surface_text: He started his service as a constable on a salary of Rs. 13 per month from August 1, 1930. In 1946 his pay was increased to Rs. 46 per month.

facts.text: In 1946 appellant's pay increased to Rs. 46 per month.

anchor.surface_text: In 1946 his pay was increased to Rs. 46 per month. He was appointed a Head constable on a salary of Rs. 50 per month in 1947.

facts.text: Appellant appointed Head constable on salary Rs. 50 per month in 1947.

anchor.surface_text: He was appointed a Head constable on a salary of Rs. 50 per month in 1947. He officiated as a Sub-Inspector of Police sometime in 1948 and 1949

facts.text: Appellant officiated as Sub-Inspector of Police in 1948 and 1949 on salary Rs. 150 per month.

anchor.surface_text: He officiated as a Sub-Inspector of Police sometime in 1948 and 1949 on a salary of Rs. 150 per month. On March 1, 1949, he was reverted

facts.text: On March 1, 1949, appellant reverted to post of Head constable.

anchor.surface_text: On March 1, 1949, he was reverted to his post of Head constable. Between the dates February 27, 1951, and September 9, 1952,

facts.text: Between February 27, 1951, and September 9, 1952, appellant posted as Head constable attached to Sadar Malkhana, Kanpur.

anchor.surface_text: Between the dates February 27, 1951, and September 9, 1952, he was posted as a Head constable attached to the Sadar Malkhana, Kanpur. The charge against him was that in that capacity he dishonestly or fraudulently misappropriated

facts.text: Charge: appellant dishonestly or fraudulently misappropriated articles seized in connection with excise offences kept in Sadar Malkhana, including opium, bottles of liquor.

anchor.surface_text: The charge against him was that in that capacity he dishonestly or fraudulently misappropriated or otherwise converted to his own use many articles, principally those seized in connection with excise offences kept in deposit in the said Malkhana. These articles included opium, bottles of liquor etc.

facts.text: Sum of Rs. 9,284-1-0 recovered on search of appellant's house on September 9 and 10, 1952, disproportionate to known sources of income.

anchor.surface_text: The charge further stated that a sum of Rs. 9,284-1-0 was recovered on a search of his house on September 9 and 10, 1952 and this amount was disproportionate to the known sources of income of the appellant.

facts.text: Prosecution alleged acts committed by appellant in conspiracy with Bhagawat Singh and Gulab Singh.

anchor.surface_text: There was an allegation by the prosecution that the acts of dishonest misappropriation etc. were committed by the appellant in conspiracy with two other persons called Bhagawat Singh and Gulab Singh.

facts.text: Charges against appellant: 1. conspiracy under s.120B IPC, 2. under s.5(1)(c) PC Act read with s.5(2), 3. s.465 IPC for forged entry in Register.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, the charges against the appellant were (1) for the offence of conspiracy under s. 120B of the Indian Penal Code (2) for the offence under s. 5(1)(c) of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947, for the acts of dishonest misappropriation or user, read with s. 5(2) of the said Act and (3) for an offence under s. 465 of the Indian Penal Code in respect of a particular entry said to have been forged in the Register of Properties kept in the Sadar Malkhana.

facts.text: Special Judge acquitted Bhagawat Singh and Gulab Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Special Judge who tried the appellant Bhagawat Singh and Gulab Singh recorded an order of acquittal in respect of the latter two persons.

facts.text: Special Judge acquitted appellant on all charges except under s.5(2) PC Act, convicted on that.

anchor.surface_text: As to the appellant, he was also acquitted of all the charges except the charge under s. 5(2) of the Prevention of Corruption Act. On this charge the learned Special Judge recorded an order of conviction, but this was based on the sole ground that the appellant had failed to account satisfactorily for the possession of Rs. 9,284-1-0

facts.text: Special Judge found Rs. 9,284-1-0 disproportionate to known sources of income and appellant failed to satisfactorily account for it.

anchor.surface_text: ...conviction, but this was based on the sole ground that the appellant had failed to account satisfactorily for the possession of Rs. 9,284-1-0 which, according to the finding of the learned Special Judge, was disproportionate to the known sources of income of the appellant.

facts.text: Special Judge held appellant not guilty of various acts of dishonest misappropriation of properties in Sadar Malkhana.

anchor.surface_text: It should be noted here that the learned Special Judge held the appellant not guilty of the various acts of dishonest misappropriation or user alleged against him in respect of the properties kept in the Sadar Malkhana.

facts.text: Appellant appealed to High Court urging cannot be convicted on presumption under s.5(3) when not guilty under s.5(1)(c).

anchor.surface_text: In his appeal to the High Court the appellant urged various grounds, one of which was that he could not be convicted on the rule of presumption laid down in sub-s. (3) of s. 5 of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947, when on the only charge of criminal misconduct alleged under s. 5(1)(c) of the said Act he had been found not guilty.

facts.text: High Court repelled appellant's contention, upheld conviction but reduced sentence.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court repelled this contention and upheld the conviction of the appellant but reduced the sentence. The principal question before us is whether in the circumstances of this case,

facts.text: Appellant gave explanation for possession of Rs. 9,284-1-0 which was not accepted by courts below.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, it appears, gave some explanation with regard to the possession of Rs. 9,284-1-0. That explanation was not, however, accepted by the courts below.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds argument of appellant correct and conviction cannot stand.

anchor.surface_text: We consider that the above argument of learned Counsel for the appellant is correct and must be, accepted.

facts.text: Special Judge and High Court erred by treating s.5(2) or s.5(3) as creating offence independent of s.5(1) categories.

anchor.surface_text: It appears to us that the learned Special Judge and the High Court proceeded wrongly on the footing as though sub-s. (2) or sub-s. (3) of s. 5 of the Act creates an offence.

issues.text: whether in the circumstances of this case, the conviction of the appellant on the charge under sub-s. 2 of s. 5 of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947, by invoking the rule of presumption as laid down in sub-s. 3 of that section, is correct

arguments.claim: Cannot be convicted under s.5(2) of Prevention of Corruption Act using presumption under s.5(3) when found not guilty on the only charge of criminal misconduct under s.5(1)(c)

anchor.surface_text: In his appeal to the High Court the appellant urged various grounds, one of which was that he could not be convicted on the rule of presumption laid down in sub-s. (3) of s. 5 of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947, when on the only charge of criminal misconduct alleged under s. 5(1)(c) of the said Act he had been found not guilty. The High Court repelle

court_response_anchor.surface_text: l companyrt held the accused person in that case number guilty of the offence under cl.  a  but guil

arguments.court_reasoning: Argument correct; statutory scheme requires criminal misconduct under s.5(1) categories as foundation for s.5(2) punishment and s.5(3) presumption

arguments.claim: Scheme of s.5: sub-s.(1) defines criminal misconduct in categories (a)-(d); sub-s.(2) provides punishment therefor; sub-s.(3) presumption applies only to those charged offences; since acquitted under sole charge s.5(1)(c), cannot invoke presumption for conviction

anchor.surface_text: Learned Counsel has submitted, however, that the scheme of s. 5 of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947 is this sub-s. (1) defines the offence of criminal misconduct in the discharge of his duties by a public servant the offence can be one or more of four categories mentioned in cls. (a), (b), (c) and (d) sub-s. (2) is the penal section which states the punishment for the offence of criminal misconduct and sub-s. (3) lays down a rule of presumption and states that no conviction for the offence shall be invalid by reason only that it is based solely on such presumption. Learned Counsel has pointed out, rightly in our opinion, that the charge against the appellant in the present case referred only to criminal misconduct in the discharge of his duty by a public servant of the nature mentioned in cl. (c) of sub-s. (1).

court_response_anchor.surface_text: l companyrt held the accused person in that case number guilty of the offence under cl.  a  but guil

arguments.court_reasoning: We consider the argument correct and accept it; confirms s.5(3) presumption requires foundation in s.5(1) category

It should be noted here that the learned Special Judge held the appellant not guilty of the various acts of dishonest misappropriation or user alleged against him

arguments.claim: Open to appellate court to affirm conviction under s.5(2) by holding appellant guilty of criminal misconduct under cl.(a) or cl.(d) of s.5(1)

anchor.surface_text: Learned Counsel for the respondent State has contended before us that it was open to the appellate Court to affirm the conviction of the appellant under sub-s. (2) of s. 5 by holding him guilty of the offence of criminal misconduct of the category mentioned in cl. (a) or cl. (d) of sub-s. (1).

arguments.court_reasoning: Prosecution never alleged basis in (a)/(d); appellate court cannot introduce entirely new case never put to accused

arguments.claim: s.5(3) lays down rule of evidence presuming guilt of charged criminal misconduct, not new offence; distinguished from Swamy where multiple s.5(1) charges existed

anchor.surface_text: We consider that the above argument of learned Counsel for the appellant is correct and must be, accepted. This Court pointed out in C. S. D. Swamy v. The State (1) that sub-s. (3) of s. 5 of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947 does not create a new offence but only lays down a rule of evidence which empowers the Court to presume the guilt of the accused in certain circumstances, contrary to the well known principle of Criminal law that the burden of proof is always on the prosecution and never shifts on to the accused person. In Swamys case there were charges for the offence of criminal misconduct under two heads, cl. (a) and cl. (d).

arguments.claim: s.5(2) and s.5(3) do not create independent offence; must be based on criminal misconduct in one or more categories under s.5(1)(a)-(d)

anchor.surface_text: It appears to us that the learned Special Judge and the High Court proceeded wrongly on the footing as though sub-s. (2) or sub-s. (3) of s. 5 of the Act creates an offence. The offence which is punished under sub-s. (2) or can be founded on the rule of presumption laid down in sub-s. (3) must be the offence of criminal misconduct of one or more of the categories mentioned in cls. (a) to (d) of sub-s. (1).

holdings.text: We consider that the above argument of learned Counsel for the appellant is correct and must be, accepted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepts petitioner's textual and harmonious interpretation of s.5 scheme; s.5(3) presumption applies only to charged s.5(1) categories; distinguishes from Swamy where multiple charges existed.

holdings.text: sub-s. (3) of s. 5 of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947 does not create a new offence but only lays down a rule of evidence which empowers the Court to presume the guilt of the accused in certain circumstances

anchor.surface_text: . This Court pointed out in C. S. D. Swamy v. The State (1) that sub-s. (3) of s. 5 of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947 does not create a new offence but only lays down a rule of evidence which empowers the Court to presume the guilt of the accused in certain circumstances, contrary to the well known principle

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Swamy precedent that s.5(3) is evidentiary presumption, not substantive offence; applies to facts where no viable s.5(1) charge remains after acquittal.

holdings.text: It appears to us that the learned Special Judge and the High Court proceeded wrongly on the footing as though sub-s. (2) or sub-s. (3) of s. 5 of the Act creates an offence. The offence which is punished under sub-s. (2) or can be founded on the rule of presumption laid down in sub-s. (3) must be the offence of criminal misconduct of one or more of the categories mentioned in cls. (a) to (d) of sub-s. (1).

anchor.surface_text: It appears to us that the learned Special Judge and the High Court proceeded wrongly on the footing as though sub-s. (2) or sub-s. (3) of s. 5 of the Act creates an offence. The offence which is punished under sub-s. (2) or can be founded on the rule of presumption laid down in sub-s. (3) must be the

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual and harmonious construction of s.5: s.5(1) defines offence in mandatory categories (a)-(d); s.5(2) punishes and s.5(3) presumes only those; lower courts erred treating (2)/(3) independently.

holdings.text: in our case there is only one charge of criminal misconduct of which the appellant has been acquitted therefore, there is no other charge which can be founded on the rule of presumption referred to in sub-s. (3).

anchor.surface_text: The distinction between that case and the case under our consideration is this in Swamys case there were two charges either of which could be founded on the rule of presumption laid down in sub-s. (3) but

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies Swamy distinction: presumption unavailable without surviving charged s.5(1) category; sole s.5(1)(c) charge failed.

holdings.text: We are unable to accept this contention as correct. The prosecution never alleged that the sum of Rs. 9,284-1-0 was the result of the appellant habitually accepting or obtaining illegal gratification etc. The prosecution case was that the sum of Rs. 9,284-1-0 was the result of the dishonest user of property which was entrusted with the appellant. It is not open to the appellate Court to affirm the conviction of the Appellant on an entirely new case never suggested against the appellant at any earlier stage.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects conversion to uncharged s.5(1)(a)/(d); no prosecution case on those; appellate power limited, cannot make new case.
